Introduction Ammonia NH3 plays an extremely important role in modern society, which is the raw material for the manufacture of nitrogen fertilizer, nitrogen-containing medicines, polymer materials, dyes and so on.13 The global annual ammonia production has reached 235 million tons in 2019.4 Up to now, industrial ammonia synthesis heavily relies on the century-old Haber-Bosch process, in which nitrogen N2 and hydrogen H2 are reacted to NH3 using Fe-base material as a catalyst at harsh conditions temperature 400500 C, pressure 150300 atm. Due to the harsh conditions and the huge ammonia production in the world, NH3 synthesis industry consumes about 1-2 of the global annual energy demand, accounting for about 1 of the carbon dioxide CO2 emission.5,6 Hence, it is very urgent to develop a green, sustainable and energy-saving ammonia synthesis technology to partially replace the Haber-Bosch process. Electricity driven nitrates reduction reaction NO3RR is regarded as a powerful complement to the traditional Haber-Bosch process toward large-scale ammonia synthesis. Benefitting from the extremely high solubility of the nitrate ions, and relative low bond energy of NO 204 kJ mol1, the ammonia generation kinetics of NO3RR is increased by 3-4 orders of magnitude with relatively low energy input in comparison to the fascinating nitrogen reduction reaction NRR.716 Moreover, nitrates are widely existed in nature, mainly derived from industrial wastewater, domestic sewage, livestock manure and nuclear industry wastewater.17 Beyond that, NO3RR possesses high equilibrium potential of 0.69 V versus the reversible hydrogen electrode RHE, higher than that of the oxygen reduction reaction ORR, 0.4 V in Znairoxygen batteries.18,19 As such, integrating of NO3RR as a cathode coupled with zinc oxidation as an anode to assemble zinc-nitrate battery, can achieve the goal of one stone and three birds, namely the removal of nitrates, obtaining valuable ammonia and outputting electrical energy.2023 However, the current electrochemical NO3-to-NH3 conversion is still restricted by the low NH3 yield rate and Faradaic efficiency FE. 10.1002anie.202509303 Accepted Manuscript Angewandte Chemie International Edition This article is protected by copyright.

See the Terms and Conditions https:onlinelibrary.wiley.comterms-and-conditions on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License 4 Typically, NO3-to-NH3 conversion is a process involving nine protons and eight electrons NO3 9H 8eNH3 3H2O, in which the various N-intermediates undergo step-by-step hydrogenation and dehydration on the catalyst surface, ultimately convert to NH3. Currently, various strategies, including alloying,12,20 heteroatom doping,18 heterojunction,11,22 defect engineering23 have been put forward, aiming to reduce the energy barrier of the rate-determining step RDS of NO3RR.24 Nevertheless, the influence of the energy barriers of the non-RDSs in NO3RR on the overall performance was ignored. Inspired by the water flow process in nature, which always spontaneously experiences the lowest energy path, the overall NO3RR performance is bound to be optimal if each elementary step also undergoes the lowest energy barrier. For the multi-intermediates and multi-steps involved reduction process, multiple active centers nor single active center are essential to achieve the lowest energy barrier required for each conversion step as much as possible.25 Here, we put forward a novel continuous intermediates spillover strategy to enhance proton-coupled electron transfer process by constructing dual single-atom molybdenum Mo1 and iron Fe1 alloy metallene. Previous reports have confirmed that Mo and Fe single-atom sites could achieve the tandem NO3RR, which achieved high NH3 FE.26,27 In addition, the Pd metallene was chosen as the carrier due to the high specific surface area, tunable electronic structure, which endowed high electrochemical performance in catalysis.28 The atomically dispersed Mo and Fe atoms in Pd matrix facilitated N-intermediates hop back and forth between Mo and Fe sites in searching of the lower energy barrier for each elementary step, which was confirmed by in situ spectroscopic characterizations and theoretical calculations. Beyond that, atomic Mo and Fe doping regulated the interfacial water network structure to inhibit the too fast water splitting kinetics, which synchronously guaranteed high NH3 yield rate and FE. As a result, the synthesized dual single-atom alloy metallene displayed greatly enhanced NH3 yield rate and NH3 FE compared with that of the counterpart metallenes. 10.1002anie.202509303 Accepted Manuscript Angewandte Chemie International Edition This article is protected by copyright. Results and Discussion As demonstrated in Figure 1a, atomically dispersed Mo and Fe atoms in Pd metallene matrix were synthesized using an one-pot wet-chemical approach, in which Pdacac2, Fe2CO9, and MoCO6 were co-reduced at 80 C for 12 h. Carbon monoxide CO molecules in situ released from Fe2CO9 and MoCO6 adsorbed tightly on Pd-rich alloy surface, which resulted in the formation of ultrathin Pd-rich nanosheet, i.e., Pd-rich trimetallene, denotes as Mo1Fe1Pd trimetallene.28 As a control, atomically dispersed iron Fe1Pd or molybdenum Mo1Pd atoms bimetallenes, and Pd metallene were synthesized with a similar synthetic process Figures S1 and S2. Powder X-ray diffraction XRD patterns show that both Mo1Fe1Pd and the control samples possess face-centered cubic fcc structure, consistent with that of fcc Pd JCPDS no. 46-1043, Figure 1b. As determined by inductively coupled plasma-mass spectrometry ICP-MS, the molar ratios of Pd, Fe and Mo were 90:8:2. Transmission electron microscopy TEM and high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM HAADF-STEM images reveal that the sample is dominated by ultrathin nanosheet structure Figures 1c and S1a with average lateral size of about 100-200 nm. The thickness of the trimetallene is only 1.8 nm, determined by atomic force microscopy AFM measurement Figure 1d, coincided with the result determined by TEM characterization the insert in Figure 1c, further confirming the metallene structure. Atomic-resolution aberration-corrected HAADF-STEM image Figure 1e displays clear two-dimensional atom arrangement with a lattice distance of 0.195 nm at the edge of the metallene, assigning to the 100 plane of Mo1Fe1Pd. EDS elemental mapping images in Figure 1f demonstrate the uniform distribution of Mo, Fe and Pd across the entire metallene, further verifying the trimetallic alloy structure. Figure 2a shows Mo K-edge X-ray absorption near edge structure XANES spectroscopy in reference with Mo foil and MoO2. Mo extended XAFS EXAFS spectra were obtained by Fourier transform of Mo K-edge, in which MoMo bond was absent in Mo1Fe1Pd sample Figure 2b, Table S1. MoPd 2.72 Å and MoFe 2.50 Å bonds were resolved in the first shell with a coordination number CN of 3.7 and 1.7, respectively. The fine structure was further confirmed by fitting the k3-weighted Fourier transformed EXAFS spectra and k space results Figures S4a and S5a. The results indicate that Mo atoms are atomically dispersed in PdFe alloy matrix. Figure 2c and 2d shows the Fe K-edge XANES and EXAFS spectra of Mo1Fe1Pd trimetallene sample in comparison to Fe foil and FeO, respectively. Similar to Mo case, FeFe bonds were absent, and PdFe bond length 2.80 Å, CN 1.6 and FeO bonds bond length 1.96 Å, CN 3.1 were resolved. The results suggest that Fe is also atomically dispersed in PdMo alloy lattice. Notably, the existence of FeO bonds suggests Fe element was partially oxidized in the air, consistent with that of XPS results. The Fe fine structure was also verified by fitting the k3-weighted Fourier transformed EXAFS spectra and k space results Figures S4b and S5b. Pd K-edge XANES and EXAFS spectra Figures 2e, 2f, S4c, S5c resolve PdPd and PdMoFe bonds. Then, wavelet transforms WT analysis of the Mo, Fe and Pd K-edge EXAFS oscillations of Mo1Fe1Pd trimetallene sample was performed in reference with MoO2, Mo foil, Fe foil, FeO and Pd foil Figure 2g. Electrochemical NO3RR performance of Mo1Fe1Pd trimetallene was evaluated in an H-type cell using a typical three-electrode system at room temperature. Linear sweep voltammetry LSV tests were firstly performed in the mixture solution of KOH and KNO3 to assess the current response. As shown in Figure 3a, the onset potential for Mo1Fe1Pd trimetallene is positively shifted from 0.32 Pd metallene, 0.43 Fe1Pd bimetallene, 0.48 Mo1Pd bimetallene to 0.55 V versus RHE, suggesting that Mo1Fe1Pd is more active in NO3RR. As expected, the current density in NO3RR of Mo1Fe1Pd trimetallene is obvious higher than that of Mo1Pd, Fe1Pd bimetallenes, and Pd metallene. The results indicate that alloying dual single-atom Mo and Fe in Pd lattice indeed strengthens NO3RR performance of Pd metallene. Notably, the synergistic effect of dual single-atom Mo and Fe atoms doping for NO3RR was confirmed by altering Mo and Fe contents in Mo1Fe1Pd trimetallene Figures S6 and S7, and discussed in detail in the following section. Upon confirming the optimal Mo and Fe content, potential-dependent ammonia yield rates Figures 3b, S8 and ammonia FEs Figure 3c were obtained after electrolysis at the fixed potentials. Obviously, NH3 yield rates and NH3 FEs all gradually increased as the applied potentials negatively shifted from 0.1 to 0.7 V versus RHE for all the samples. Mo1Fe1Pd trimetallene delivered much higher NH3 yield rates than that of Fe1Pd, Mo1Pd bimetallenes, and Pd metallene samples over the entire potential range. The maximum NH3 yield rate of Mo1Fe1Pd trimetallene reached 13.4 mol gcat.1 h1 at 0.7 V, which was about 4.8- and 1.5-fold higher than that of Pd metallene 2.8 mol gcat.1 h1 and Fe1Pd bimetallene 9.1 mol gcat.1 h1, respectively. Consistent with the activity, NH3 FEs of Mo1Fe1Pd trimetallene all surpassed Fe1Pd, Mo1Pd bimetallenes, and Pd metallene in the potential range of 0.1 to 0.7 V. The approaching 100 NH3 FE of Mo1Fe1Pd trimetallene suggests that the competing hydrogen evolution reaction HER and the by-products in NO3RR are almost inhibited Figures S9-S11, which is vital important in real-world applications. To confirm the accuracy of the above NH3 quantitative results, the yielded NH3 in the electrolyte was further spectrographically quantified with indophenol blue assay, and the results are consistent Figure S12. In industrial scenarios, durability is an important parameter for catalyst assessment. In H-type cell, Mo1Fe1Pd trimetallene could sustain continuous thirty cycles at 0.7 V, NH3 yield rates and NH3 FEs were stable without obvious activity decay Figure S13. To further assess the stability, the catalyst was further characterized by XRD pattern and TEM measurement after durability test. The crystal structure and the morphology of the Mo1Fe1Pd trimetallene were well maintained Figure S14. A commercial silicon solar panel 1.9 W illuminated by xenon lamp 100 mW cm2 was employed to power ammonia electrosynthesis using Mo1Fe1Pd trimetallene as a catalyst in the wild environment. As expected, the yielded NH3 amounts showed a linear relationship with the illumination time, and an average NH3 yield rate reached 2.96 mol gcat.1 h1, demonstrating the potential application prospects. Upon assessing the NO3RR performance, it is essential to decode the specific role of Mo and Fe dual single-atom alloy in ammonia electrosynthesis. Figure 4a-4c shows the potential-dependent partial current densities of NO2 jNO2, ammonia jNH3 and HER jH2 for Mo1Fe1Pd trimetallene in comparison to Fe1Pd, Mo1Pd bimetallenes, and Pd metallene, respectively Figure S21. For NO3NO2 conversion, the jNO2 arranges as follow: Mo1Pd Pd Fe1Pd Mo1Fe1Pd Figure 4a. In contrast, the jNH3 is listed as Mo1Fe1Pd Fe1Pd Mo1Pd Pd. By comparing the results of Fe1Pd, Mo1Pd and Pd samples, it is concluded that alloying single-atom Mo in Pd matrix greatly enhances jNO2, while single-atom Fe in Pd lattice increases jNH3 and weakens jNO2. Considering the promotion effect of single-atom Mo and Fe on process i and ii, alloying dual single-atom Mo and Fe in Pd lattice may cascade NO3NO2 by Mo and NO2NH3 by Fe processes in NO3RR. The above supposition was verified by the smallest jNO2 and the largest jNH3 of Mo1Fe1Pd trimetallene. As a major side reaction, water splitting process not only releases hydrogen, but also provides active hydrogen H atoms. As nine H are involved in NO3RR, therefore the kinetics of water splitting greatly determines the final NH3 yield rate and NH3 FE, especially in the more negative potential area. On the one hand, the sluggish kinetics of water splitting process is not enough to provide sufficient H for the subsequent deoxyreduction processes, resulting in weakened NH3 yield rate. However, the too fast kinetics of water splitting boosts H formation and aggravates HER, leading to an awful NH3 FE. The trade-off water splitting activity directly determines NH3 yield rate and NH3 FE. As shown in Figure 4c, jH2 is declined for Mo1Fe1Pd trimetallene in comparison to Fe1Pd bimetallene and Pd metallene, comparable with that of Mo1Pd bimetallene. As a result, the N-selectivity of NH3 was greatly enhanced, and NO2 was completely suppressed for Mo1Fe1Pd trimetallene Figure S22. Beyond that, the chemical redox reaction of Pd and NO3 also contributed the NO2 formation in NO3RR, similar with the role of single-atom Mo. The oxidized Pd species was further reduced to metallic Pd in the operation of NO3RR Figures S23-S25.37 Based on the above analysis, the detailed mechanism of dual single-atom Mo and Fe in Pd for NO3RR was summarized in Figure S26. Moreover, electrochemical active surface area ECSA was also obtained, Mo1Fe1Pd trimetallene delivered a higher ECSA than that of Mo1Pd, Fe1Pd bimetallenes, and Pd metallene, which also contributed to the enhanced NO3RR performance Figure S27. To further investigate why the single-atom Mo and Fe sites can cascade NO3RR, in situ spectroscopic characterizations were carried out to clarify the reaction pathway. Potential-dependent in situ attenuated total reflection flourier transform infrared spectroscopy ATR-FTIR measurements were conducted both for Mo1Fe1Pd, Mo1Pd, Fe1Pd samples. Figure 4d-4f shows the potential-resolved ATR-FTIR spectra in NO3RR from 0 to 0.9 V V versus RHE of Mo1Fe1Pd, Fe1Pd and Mo1Pd samples, respectively. As shown in Figure 4d, the signal of NO3 and NO2 located at 1193 and 1230 cm1 was emerged at 0.1 V, indicating the conversion of NO3 to NO2.38,39 Then, three obvious vibration peaks located at 1010, 1082 and 1340 cm1 arose at 0.2 V, which were attributed to ρasNH2, νNO and νNH4, respectively, suggesting the formation of NH3.3941 Compared with NO2, the intensity of ρasNH2 and νNH4 increased sharply when the applied potential was lower than 0.35 V, suggesting the accelerated conversion of NO3-to-NH3. The peak located at 1641 cm1 was assigned to νO-H of interfacial H2O molecule.44 The above possible pathway coincided with that of in situ Raman spectra in NO3RR Figure S28. Notably, the signal of the key intermediates was all emerged on Fe1Pd bimetallene Figure 4e, Mo1Pd bimetallene Figure 4f and Pd metallene Figure S29, suggesting the similar reaction pathway on Fe1Pd, Mo1Pd bimetallenes, and Pd metallene. That is to say dual single-atom Mo and Fe doping in Pd matrix does not change the reaction pathway of NO3RR. Moreover, it should be emphasized that Mo1Fe1Pd sample delivered higher ATR-FTIR intensity than that of Fe1Pd, Mo1Pd bimetallenes, and Pd metallene, proofing the enhanced NO3RR performance of Mo1Fe1Pd. As a stark contrast, only the signal of ρasNH2 and νNH4 with much lower intensity was observed on Pd metallene, further confirming the greatly enhanced NO3RR performance of dual single-atom Mo and Fe alloy trimetallene. In addition to the type and strength of the N-intermediates signal, it was observed the difference of the position for NO, NH2OH and NH2. Specifically, the signal of NO arose at 1439 and 1511 cm1 for Fe1Pd and Mo1Pd, respectively. While, the signal of NO was located at 1511 cm1 for Mo1Fe1Pd, coincided with that of Mo1Pd Figure 4g. As determined by XAFS results, Mo1Fe1Pd sample possesses two distinct sites, i.e., Mo and Fe sites, therefore, it is inferred that NO could be adsorbed on Mo site for Mo1Fe1Pd sample. Accordingly, the ATR-FTIR signal of NH2OH and NH2 were located at 1545 and 1010 cm1 for Mo1Fe1Pd sample, more closer to that of Mo1Pd and Fe1Pd samples, respectively. The results indicate that NH2OH could be adsorbed on Mo site, while NH2 was adsorbed on Fe site. Conclusions In summary, a highly efficient and durable dual single-atom Mo1Fe1Pd alloy metallene was synthesized for electrochemical nitrate conversion to ammonia. Atomically dispersed molybdenum and iron atoms in Pd lattice provided two distinct catalytic sites, enabling the continuous intermediates spillover between Mo and Fe sites. So that NO3RR experienced the lowest energy barrier for each elementary step, which was confirmed by in situ spectroscopic characterizations and theoretical calculations. Furthermore, the co-doping of Mo and Fe atoms altered the interfacial water structure to restrain the competing HER, as well as regulated the electronic structure, resulting in high NH3 yield rate and NH3 FE synchronously. Mo1Fe1Pd trimetallene delivered a remarkable NH3 yield rate of 13.4 mol gcat.1 h1 and NH3 FE of 94.6, as well as excellent cycling stability. Moreover, the assembled zinc-nitrate battery delivered an OCV of 1.477 V, and the maximum output power density of 13.4 mW cm2. This work provides new insights into the design of efficient, selective and durable electrocatalysts for multi-steps and multi-intermediates involved electrosynthesis process from the angle of intermediates hopping effect. text: Elucidating the Activity of Electrochemical Nitrate Reduction: High- Valent Anionic Intermediates as Kinetic Gatekeepers Sheng-Jie Qian, Hao Cao, Xin-Mao Lv, Jun Li, and Yang-Gang Wang Cite This: https:doi.org10.1021jacs.5c05728 Read Online ACCESS Metrics More Article Recommendations sı Supporting Information ABSTRACT: The persistent paradox in electrochemical nitrate reduction NO3 RRthe requirement of high overpotentials despite its highly exothermic natureremains a critical roadblock for efficient ammonia electrosynthesis. Here, we resolve this conundrum by identifying a high- valent anionic intermediate as kinetic gatekeepers during the nitrate reduction on a single-atom catalyst by using AIMD simulations under explicit solvation and electrode potentials. Employing our self-developed constant-potential thermodynamic integration method, we reveal a stark kinetic barrier dichotomy: while the reaction is thermodynamically favorable governed by the NO break, the protonation to oxygen at a low anionic state necessitates substantial activation energy. Mechanistic analysis uncovers that electrode polarization preactivates NO3 into a metastable high-valent NO3 2 intermediate, which serves as the key step to the following protonation process. Crucially, this intermediates stabilization requires a highly negative potential, directly linking its formation to the observed overpotential. Furthermore, molecular dynamics simulations also demonstrate that K cations play a key role in electrostatically stabilizing the adsorption of negatively charged NO3 onto the negatively polarized cathode. This work calls for the urgent reconsideration of conventional nitrate reduction mechanisms and the exigency of refined interface design principles for improved nitrate electrocatalysis. INTRODUCTION Since the 1980s, electrochemical nitrate reduction NO3 RR has traditionally been proposed for sewage treatment, facilitating the conversion of nitrate into innocuous nitrogen N2.13 Recently, there has emerged a revitalized interest in NO3 RR, motivated by the goal of producing ammonia NH3 instead.4,5 Therefore, electrochemical nitrate reduction repre- sents a sustainable pathway and a promising route for both water treatment and ammonia generation. The practical applications of NO3 RR in energy and environment, however, face a significant challenge due to its exceptionally high overpotential, despite the thermodynamically favorable path- ways with theoretical equilibrium potentials of 1.17 V vs SHE for N2 and 0.12 V vs SHE for NH3 formation. The universal initial two-electron 2e reduction of nitrate to nitrite is generally identified to be a rate-determining step.68 There are two popular contradictory hypotheses regarding the mechanism of reduction of nitrate to nitrite in the NO3 RR. One genre believes that nitrate reduction begins with a protonation process where NO3 interacts with H in solution to form adsorbed HNO3 at the electrode NO3 H HNO3, which is considered a solution-mediated proton transfer reaction and does not require electron transfer.9,10 Then, the formed HNO3 undergoes a process of protonation and dehydration to produce NO2. However, this does not conform to the common chemical knowledge that HNO3 is a strong electrolyte and would inevitably electrolyze into the proton and nitrate ion. The other representation points out that NO3 first undergoes an oxidative associative adsorption, where NO3 is adsorbed and discharged to form NO3 NO3 NO3 e.7,8,1115 Subsequent reduction and hydrogenation pro- cesses lead to the formation of NO2 or NO2 . However, the oxidative adsorption is unlikely to proceed at the cathode electrode, where the electroreduction of NO3 is operated. Therefore, the mechanism of nitrate anion adsorption on the cathode remains controversial, and the origin of the high overpotential required for NO3 reduction is still poorly understood. Metalnitrogencarbon MNC, M Fe, Co, Mn, Ni, etc. single atom electrocatalysts,16,17 with a well-defined atomic structure, have emerged as a class of ideal model systems for fundamental studies to investigate the electro- catalytic mechanism. A large number of DFT calculations based on the CHE model have indicated that the rate-determining step of the transition of nitrate to nitrite is markedly exothermic. However, many catalysts such as Fe NC catalysts exhibit a significant overpotential exceeding 0.6 V.79,11,12,2022 Therefore, current theoretical calculations fail to explain the origin of the high overpotential, strongly suggesting that previously overlooked dynamic processes or complex interface effects may have played a key role. It is only within the past few years that an ever-increasing understanding of dynamically electrified solidliquid interfaces has started to trigger a return to this foundational pillar of electrochemistry, namely, uncovering the roles of electrode potential and solvent in electrochemical reactions under realistic electrochemical conditions,23,24 notably, in the CO2RR,25,26 ORR,27 and NRR.28 Unlike these neutrally charged small molecule reactants like CO2 and N2, NO3 ions are negatively charged in solution, which is expected to result in a significantly different mechanism. Nevertheless, it is fair to acknowledge that no study has yet provided a definitive description of the reduction behavior of NO3 at the electrodeelectrolyte interfaces. Here, we uncover the origin of the high overpotential for NO3 RR on the FeNC catalyst by employing the self- developed constant potential kinetic modeling method. Specifically, the critical roles of electrode potential and cations in the reaction mechanism were revealed. The 2ereduction pathway from nitrate to nitrite is characterized as exothermic thermodynamically, but our calculations show a notable kinetic energy barrier that must be surmounted. We then investigated the adsorption behavior of nitrate by collecting bond length and charge in AIMD simulations, as shown in Figure 1. NO3 is adsorbed on the FeN4C catalyst via an end-on configuration, in which one O atom of the nitrate binds with the Fe center. It can be observed in Figure 1a that the length of the FeO bond in the K-Back model remains at 2 Å until the number of K ions increase to 5, when it suddenly becomes longer longer than 5 Å. This indicates that NO3 is desorbed due to the electrostatic repulsion with the negatively polarized electrode surface as the number of K increases. By contrast, the FeO bond length in the K-Inter model fluctuates in the range of 23 Å, where the location of nitrate is perturbed by the dynamic distribution of K at the interface. These results demonstrate that the K cations play a crucial stabilizing role in the nitrate anion adsorption process. In the K-Back model, the NO3 species maintains both its monovalent character of 0.85 e and a N O bond length of 1.27 Å across the entire potential window. Notably, a potential-dependent charge accumulation phenom- enon was observed in the K-Inter model. At an electrode potential of around 0.8 V vs RHE, we observed a significant additional charge transfer of about 0.6 e to NO3 Figure 1b, converting to a high-valent NO3 2 anion. This transformation is accompanied by a distinct structural change, as evidenced by the elongation of the average NO bond length from 1.27 to 1.37 Å, indicative of nitrate activation. The stabilized adsorption of the high-valent NO3 2species can be attributed to enhanced electrostatic interactions with neighboring K cations, as confirmed by our electronic structure analysis Figure S6. These findings demonstrate a unique nitrate activation that is specifically enabled by the K-Inter model, highlighting the crucial role of electrostatic interactions in stabilizing nitrate adsorption at the electrified interfaces. Further, our recently developed Constant-Potential Ther- modynamic Integration CPTI method29,30 was employed to calculate the reaction energetics of nitrate adsorption in K- Inter and K-Back models at the electrode potential of 0.82 V. The CPTI method enables realistic modeling of the electrochemical interface, and the efficient free energy calculations are based on a robust surface charge density descriptor. At each collective variable CV chosen along with the reaction pathways, the CPTI method was applied to regulate the total number of electrons of the system to keep the electrode potential constant. By collecting the mean force of constraint at each CV Figure S7 and integrating over the mean force of constraint with respect to the CV, the free energy under fixed potential can be computed. Intriguingly, when NO3 is first activated to NO3 2by a reduction step, the subsequent protonation and one-electron reduction processes to form NO2 are significantly facilitated. However, the reduction potential required for the conversion of NO3 to NO3 2is highly negative, accounting for the experimentally observed high overpotential for nitrate reduction. Our calculations reveal that it is a decoupled process where electron transfer precedes proton transfer in the 2ereduction process. That is why the traditional CHE model failed in this system as the model assumes a coupled proton and electron transfer. Consequently, it is indicated that the preactivation of NO3 is the potential- determining step, while the protonation process is the rate- determining step during the 2enitrate reduction. Further- more, the essential role of electrode potential in accelerating reaction kinetics through preactivation of NO3 to NO3 2is highlighted. When the electrode potential drops to the reduction potential, one electron transfers from the electrode to the nitrate at the interface, converting NO3 into high-valent NO3 2. Under this electrode potential, the electrostatic repulsion between the electrode and NO3 2is strengthened, while the corresponding electrostatic attraction between K and NO3 2is also enhanced, thereby stabilizing the adsorption of NO3 2for subsequent reactions. Once the reduction potential of NO3 to NO3 2is reached, the protonation process becomes kinetically more favorable, allowing the 2ereduction from NO3 to NO2 to proceed efficiently. We reaffirm that the high-valent NO3 2anion predicted in our theoretical study during the two-electron reduction of nitrate is metastable with a very short lifetime. It is anticipated that advanced time-resolved spectroscopic techni- ques may enable its detection in future studies. Strategies such as the cation,31 electrode potential,32 halogen electrolyte,33 and heterostructure34,35 have been proposed to improve the performance of electrocatalytic nitrate reduction. For example, Wen et al.31 found that K can regulate the electrostatic potential distribution and proton transport in the electric double layer, thus enhancing the kinetics for the conversion of NO3 . Moreover, a series of alkali metal ions Li, Na, K were compared, and it was found that due to the smallest radius of K hydrated cations, the effects were more significant in promoting charge transfer and nitrate reduction. Guo et al.32 proposed to unitize electrode potential to control the active siteintermediate interactions to enhance NO reduction reactivity on oxygen vacancy-modified TiO2. These studies support our calculations here that alkali metal cations can promote the adsorption of nitrate ions, highlighting the key regulatory role of the electrochemical interface micro- environment including electrode potential and electrolyte composition in the kinetics of electrocatalytic reduction reactions. Future studies could further discuss the effects of different species of cation. We anticipate that our work will inspire the development of refined interface design principles for improved nitrate electrocatalysis. CONCLUSIONS In this work, a full explicit model combined with constant potential modeling based on density functional theory was employed. Our work resolves a long-standing puzzle of the high overpotential in nitrate reduction by revealing the mechanism with a particular emphasis on the roles of electrode potential and cations. First, NO3 is observed to absorb on the negatively polarized electrode surface as an anionic species. Subsequently, constant potential kinetics calculations indicate that the 2ereduction pathway from nitrate to nitrite is thermodynamically exothermic, yet it encounters a significant reaction energy barrier. Further, the first electron transfer, driven by the electrode potential, activates NO3 to NO3 2 and emerges as the key of 2ereduction of nitrate to nitrite. text: Electrochromic Rutile with Dynamically Tailored Surfaces in Formaldehyde-Mediated Hydroxylamine Electrosynthesis Jiaqi Zhang, Erbo Zhao, Chou-Hung Hsueh, Weng-Chon Max Cheong, Xin Tan, Chuhao Liu, Xiang Liu, Jinxin Wang, Hai Xiao, and Chen Chen Cite This: https:doi.org10.1021jacs.5c03124 Read Online ACCESS Metrics More Article Recommendations sı Supporting Information ABSTRACT: Electrocatalytic nitrate reduction is an attractive route for sustainable hydroxylamine synthesis, but its selectivity is limited by over-reduction and competing hydrogen evolution, highlighting the need for in-depth mechanistic understanding to guide catalyst design. Here, we systematically investigate the electrochemical synthesis of hydroxylamine via a formaldehyde-mediated method on titanium oxides. An electrochromic rutile array prepared via a wet-chemical route achieved a Faradaic efficiency FE of 92.6 for formaldehyde oxime and a corresponding yield rate of up to 2085 μmol cm2 h1 under ambient conditions. Mechanistic studies reveal that the electrochromism is a macroscopic manifestation of the protonation of Ob bridging oxygen sites and the formation of Ov oxygen vacancies and Ti3, which act as proton sponges and electron reservoirs. Formaldehyde not only serves as the capturing agent but also helps to stabilize NH2OH through molecular tuning, thereby achieving high selectivity. Through formaldehyde-nitrate electro-reforming, hydrogen, formic acid, and hydroxylamine can be coproduced at 200 mA cm2 under an ultralow cell voltage of 0.78 V. This work links the catalytic performance of hydroxylamine electrosynthesis to the dynamic surface of titanium oxides, offering insights into selectivity control in nitrate electroreduction and providing a green, cost-effective alternative to conventional hydroxylamine synthesis. INTRODUCTION Nitrogen is a vital element for all life forms and plays a crucial role in industrial production and daily life.1,2 However, the industrial processes and artificial nitrogen conversions have elicited a persistent imbalance in the nitrogen cycle Figure 1a, resulting in the accumulation of harmful nitrates and nitrites in environment, thereby leading to a series of ecological crises.35 In recent years, the electroreduction of nitrate NO3 and nitrite NO2 , preferably powered by renewable energy, has emerged as a promising strategy to restore a balanced nitrogen cycle, garnering increasing attention.68 Electrochemical nitrate reduction NO3RR effectively removes nitrate pollutants from wastewater and converts it into valuable chemicals, facilitating the recycling of nitrogen resources9,10 Current research focuses primarily on two strategies Figure 1b: reducing NO3 into dinitrogen N2 for water purification11 and converting NO3 into ammonia NH3 for nitrogen fertilizer production.12 The main by- products in these processes are hydrogen and nitrite NO2 , with barely any other products reported. Hydroxylamine NH2OH is an important nitrogenous feedstock and is extensively used in synthesizing various nitrogen-containing compounds in the chemical, pharmaceut- ical and agrochemical industries.1315 Conventional hydroxyl- amine synthesis encompasses diverse routes Raschig, hydro- genations, often facing challenges like multistep processes, byproduct generation, or reliance on harsh conditions, motivating greener electrochemical approaches.1618 In contrast, the route of reducing nitrate into hydroxylamine NO3 to NH2OH using water as the proton source and powered by renewable energy could not only effectively remove the nitrate pollutants from wastewater but also provide a more sustainable avenue toward green production of hydroxylamine. Inspired by strategies using surface adsorbates to modulate catalytic activity, here we hypothesize that mediators like formaldehyde may play a role more than simply capturing the NH2OH intermediate, but also potentially tuning the reaction pathway via surface interactions. To explore this potential molecular tuning effect27,28 and to develop high-efficiency hydroxylamine synthesis systems, transition metal oxides with rich surface chemistry and tunable structures offer an attractive platform. In particular, titanium dioxide TiO2 has garnered extensive attention by virtue of its stability, cost-effectiveness, and the known role of surface defects like Ov oxygen vacancies in catalysis. We observed that the FE for CH2NOH exhibits a saturation at higher concentrations, while the overall yield rate follows a volcano-like trend owing to decreasing current density. Since DEMS detects the intermediates extracted from the near-surface region, its ability to observe specific intermediates depends on their surface kinetics and adsorption strength. Additionally, H exists on the Ti surface bonded to Ob, allowing for a high mobility through the hydrogen bonding network, generating a self-sustained hydrogen spillover.52 Furthermore, H may also insert into the TiO2 lattice to form HTiO2 with lattice H, enabling reversible hydrogen storage, which collectively facilitates the on-demand supply of hydrogen.40 The vacancies and adsorbed species as electron donors introduce new energy levels, while the surplus 3d orbital electrons of Ti occupy the Ov, enhancing the metallic characteristics of TiO2x and improving the conductivity to promote electron transport. In the presence of formaldehyde, HCHO competes for adsorption with H, thereby influencing the concentrations of Ti3 and Ov. Under electrochemical reduction conditions in aqueous solution, chemically adsorbed HCHO predominantly exists in a stable Ti5cOCH2Ob form. Through spatial effects and electronic modulation, this process constrains the kinetics of nitrate reduction and stabilizes the NH2OH intermediate, enabling efficient electrosynthesis of the coupling product CH2NOH across a wide potential range. Theoretical Investigations via DFT Calculations. To gain a more comprehensive understanding of the mechanism of nitrate electroreduction on the rutile surface and the potential regulating role of formaldehyde in this process, we conducted spin-polarized density functional theory DFT calculations on all possible pathways for the overall reaction. As electron microscopy characterizations and geometric analysis have shown in Figure 3b, the 110 plane is the exposed facet. Thus, the rutile 110 surface with a symmetric structure of Ti5c and Ob was constructed as the active surface. Given the complexity of the nitrate electroreduction mechanism on the TiO2 surface, we calculated the most stable adsorption configurations of all intermediates on the rutile surface as illustrated in Figures S41, S42 and systematically studied the evolution pathways of the active species in NO3RR Tables S6, S7. To validate our hypothesis regarding the RDS derived from Tafel analysis, we calculated the energetics for Ov formation on both an ideal rutile 110 surface and an OBu n-butanol- terminated model surface. The results detailed in Figure S43 revealed that the RDS for Ov generation on the OBu- terminated surface is indeed the initial electron transfer protonation step Step 1 in our proposed scheme, with a barrier of 0.64 eV. This finding strongly supports our interpretation of the experimental Tafel slope 120 mV dec and confirms that active site formation probably governs the overall reaction kinetics in our system. With the understanding that Ov generation is the kinetic bottleneck, we then used DFT to investigate the subsequent reaction pathway initiated by the facile activation of nitrate on these Ov sites. In this process, the electrons previously stored at Ti3 could be released synchronously, resulting in an altered local charge density that activates the NO bond in the inserted NO3 , effectively cleaving NO3 to generate NO2 , while the recovered Ov now exists as OH. This step NO3 H NO2 OH is highly exothermic 1.95 eV, different from conventional mechanisms for nitrate electro- reduction where the activation of nitrate to nitrite occurs readily. This finding aligns well with the fact that NO2 intermediates could barely be detected in DEMS. Further, the NO2 adsorbed on Ti5c would rearrange into a bidentate adsorption ONOD configuration, followed by sequential H2O elimination to generate NO. This step has no significant thermodynamic barrier, featuring a gradual decrease in free energy. We then calculated the reaction pathway for reducing NO to NH3Figure 5b. NO would be preferentially reduced into NHO ΔG 0.05 eV rather than to NOH 0.445 eV. The conversion from NOH to N is even less favorable, thus establishing the basis for selective hydroxylamine production. Starting from NHO, NH3 could be produced via three pathways: 1 Protonation at the N end to form NH2OH, which then dissociates and undergoes H2O elimination to generate NH2. 2 Protonation at the N end to form NHOH, which undergoes H2O elimination to give NH, and then further protonated directly to NH2. 3 Protonation at the O end to form ONH2, which can either follow the NH2OH route via pathway 1 or proceed via the Langmuir Hinshelwood mechanism to directly yield ONH3 through a hydrogen atom transfer HAT process. For pathways 1 and 2, both reactions are exothermic and likely to occur, whereas pathway 3 ONH2 ONH3 has a small thermodynamic barrier ΔG 0.13 eV. To sum up, on the rutile 110 surface, nitrate electro- reduction is more likely to follow pathway 1 involving the key intermediate NH2OH. The selectivity between NH2OH and NH3 depends on the balance between the adsorption and dissociation of NH2OH. On pure rutile surfaces, NH2OH is more likely to dissociate 0.59 eV than to desorb 1.61 eV, making it rather difficult to detect NH2OH in DEMS, and therefore NH3 becomes the predominant detectable product. When formaldehyde is introduced, it adsorbs in the form of OCH2, generating the key adsorbate species Ti2OCH2O, which facilitates strong electron transfer at the TiO2 surface. Additionally, its adsorption site overlaps with the protonated Ob sites responsible for the electrochromism, leading to competitive adsorption, which explains the observed fading in electrochromism. The adsorbed HCHO significantly alters the electronic structure of the surface and affects the stability of various intermediates through intermolecular interactions. Electro-reforming System. To achieve higher yields, enhanced energy efficiency, and lower the cost of electro- catalytic hydroxylamine production, we explored an electro- reforming route for hydroxylamine synthesis. Here form- aldehyde, in addition to being the molecular modulator and capturing agent for nitrate reduction as discussed above, also served as an energy carrier. Recently, copper-based materials have been shown to be a promising approach to achieve low- potential oxidation of aldehydes and through Tafel recombi- nation to produce hydrogen and formic acid under alkaline conditions,54 with a theoretical potential of only 0.22 V. Therefore, combining anodic FOR formaldehyde oxidation reaction with cathodic formaldehyde-mediated nitrate reduc- tion for hydroxylamine synthesis presents a thermodynamically more favorable strategy Figures 5d, S44, S45. This not only generates value-added anodic products such as H2 and HCOOH, but also significantly lowers the cell voltage input and maximizes the utilization of formaldehyde. We employed Cu3Ag7CF55 as the catalyst for aldehyde oxidation dehydro- genation and used rutile array as the catalyst for hydroxylamine synthesis Figure 5e. In comparison to the 2.3 V cell voltage required for the system with OER at the anode, our system with FOR at the anode only requires 0.78 V to achieve an industrial current density of 200 mA cm2 Figure 5f, while simultaneously producing hydroxylamine, formic acid, and hydrogen Figure S46. By engineering electrocatalysts with lower overpotentials, the energy-consuming processes of nitrate electroreduction and formaldehyde electro-oxidation can be reconfigured into a formaldehyde-nitrate fuel cell that generates electrical energy, potentially achieving an open- circuit voltage OCV as high as 0.75 V Figure 5d. With its superior energy conversion efficiency, we believe that our formaldehydenitrate coelectrolysis system holds great prom- ise for industrial-scale applications. SUMMARY In conclusion, we unveiled the reaction mechanism of nitrate electroreduction into hydroxylamine mediated by formalde- hyde on various phases and surfaces of TiO2, and identified Ti5cOb as the active center. The self-supported rutile array, predominantly exposing the 110 crystal facet, exhibits a remarkable catalytic activity, achieving a Faradaic efficiency of 92.6 for CH2NOH and a yield of up to 2085 μmol cm2 h1. In addition, we found that the electrochromism of the catalyst is highly related to its catalytic activity. Specifically, this electrochromism manifests the dynamic generation of Ov and Ti3, the true active species that drive nitrate reduction via cycling processes involving Ob sites. Moreover, formaldehyde not only serves as a capturing agent but also as a molecular regulator, thereby enhancing the stability of the NH2OH intermediate and altering the reaction pathway to achieve selective reduction to give the target product. This work opens up a sustainable route to producing NH2OH under mild conditions through green electrochemistry and provides new insights into the selective regulation of nitrate reduction. See the Terms and Conditions https:onlinelibrary.wiley.comterms-and-conditions on Wiley Online Library for rules of use; OA articles are governed by the applicable Creative Commons License 2 Abstract The electrodepolyelectrolyte interface is a notable feature in modern electrochemical technologies that utilize membrane electrode assembly MEA configurations. However, its interfacial structure and catalytic behavior remain poorly understood. Here we developed an integrated operando Raman spectroscopy and mass spectrometry MS method, to directly investigate the CO2 reduction mechanism at the electrodepolyelectrolyte interface within a practical MEA electrolyzer operating at high current densities. Combined with isotope labeling experiments and ab initio molecular dynamics AIMD simulations, we provide, for the first time, the direct spectroscopic evidence of CCO, a crucial intermediate for C2 product formation, which has been frequently hypothesized but rarely detected in previous studies. By contrast, the linearly adsorbed COL intermediate, typically observed in conventional liquid electrolytes, was absent. These distinct behaviors arise from the unique structure of the electrodepolyelectrolyte interface, which shifts the rate-determining step from the usual C-C coupling to the CCO hydrogenation in the conversion of CO2 to C2 products. This study not only deepens our understanding of electrodepolyelectrolyte interfacial characteristics, but also offers valuable insights for advancing the performance of CO2 MEA electrolyzers. At the heart of these technologies is the electrodeelectrolyte interface, where electrochemical reactions occur.7 A thorough exploration of the interfacial structure and its impact on electrochemical processes is thus essential.8 This understanding is crucial for the rational design of key materials, such as efficient electrode catalysts and electrolytes, and for advancing the performance of electrochemical technologies.9 Early electrochemical studies primarily relied on electrical signals for both excitation and detection, through applying varying potentialsvoltages or currents and observing the corresponding responses to probe the electrodeelectrolyte interface.10 Since the 1970s, the introduction of various spectroscopic techniques, such as electrochemical in-situ infrared and Raman spectroscopy, has enabled the acquisition of molecular- and atomic-scale information at the electrodeelectrolyte interface during electrochemical testing,1113 significantly deepening our understanding of electrochemical interfaces and reaction mechanisms. Nevertheless, it is important to note that most electrochemical in-situ spectroscopies developed to date focus on studying the electrodeliquid electrolyte interface. In contrast, modern electrochemical technologies increasingly employ polymer electrolytes i.e., polyelectrolytes instead of liquid electrolytes e.g., HClO4, KOH solution.14 This shift enables the construction of zero-gap membrane electrode assembly MEA devices, which help reduce internal resistance and thus improve electrochemical energy conversion efficiency.15 The inherent differences between polyelectrolytes and liquid electrolytessuch as variations in ionic species organic versus inorganic and ionic mobility bound versus freeinevitably result in significant differences in the microstructure and catalytic behavior at the electrodepolyelectrolyte interface compared to the conventional electrodeliquid electrolyte interface. For instance, our recent studies have shown that CO2 reduction can occur at the electrodepolyelectrolyte interface with immobilized organic cations, a reaction that is challenging to achieve in liquid electrolytes containing free organic cations.16,17 Additionally, to facilitate spectroscopic detection, these widely used in-situ spectroscopies 10.1002anie.202509423 Accepted Manuscript Angewandte Chemie International Edition This article is protected by copyright. These variations in operating conditions can even lead to markedly different catalytic behaviors.20,21 For instance, a previous study demonstrated that while the nonprecious Mn-Co catalyst shows inferior oxygen reduction reaction ORR performance compared to PtC in aqueous KOH electrolyte, this trend reverses in alkaline polyelectrolyte fuel cells APEFCs with gas diffusion electrodes GDEs operating at 60C, due to differences in water content at the catalytic interfaces.22 Therefore, there is an urgent need to develop operando spectroscopic methods that are compatible with the operating conditions of MEA devices, to more accurately reveal the structural characteristics and catalytic behavior of the electrodepolyelectrolyte interface under practical working conditions. Indeed, some progress has been made in probing the interfaces within practical MEA-type fuel cells and water electrolyzers, through the combined use of techniques such as X-ray absorption spectroscopy XAS,23 near-ambient pressure X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy NAP-XPS,24,25 infrared spectroscopy,26,27 and Raman spectroscopy.28,29 However, operando studies focusing on CO2 MEA electrolyzers, particularly those operating in a polyelectrolytepure water medium without any liquid electrolytes, remain rather limited. In this study, we develop an integrated operando Raman spectroscopy and mass spectrometry MS method using the MEA configuration, to investigate CO2 reduction at the electrodepolyelectrolyte interface. This approach allows for the simultaneous detection of interfacially adsorbed intermediates and volatile products such as CO, CH4, C2H4, C2H5OH, and others under industrial-scale current densities, providing molecular insights into the CO2 reduction mechanism in practical MEA electrolyzers. Notably, unlike the linearly adsorbed COL intermediate commonly observed in Cu-catalyzed CO2 reduction in KOH or KHCO3 aqueous electrolytes,30 we are surprised to find that COL is absent at the electrodepolyelectrolyte interface. The counter and reference electrodes were immersed in the electrolyte solution. The excitation laser passes through a quartz window and a thin layer of the electrolyte solution, allowing the Raman scattering signals at the electrodeliquid electrolyte interface to be collected Figure S3a. Another significant observation is the complete disappearance of the νO-H band at the CuQAPEEK interface Figure 2b, 2f. This can be attributed to two factors: first, the reduced water content at the electrodepolyelectrolyte interface due to the presence of the hydrophobic backbone of QAPEEK; and second, the preservation of a strong hydrogen bonding network within the water at this interface, due to the inability of the polyelectrolyte-tethered organic cations to form a compact double layer under negative potentials, as found in our previous study.17 There is a broad consensus that Raman spectroscopy is insensitive to water, but recent research suggests that the disruption of hydrogen bonding network is critical for detecting water vibrations via surface-enhanced Raman spectroscopy.51 This explains why the νO-H band can be detected at the electrodeliquid electrolyte interface Cu1 M KHCO3, Figure 2a, whereas it cannot be detected at the electrodepolyelectrolyte interface CuQAPEEK, Figure 2b. To identify these specific species and their formation mechanism, as well as examine their relevance to CO2 reduction at the electrodepolyelectrolyte interface, various CO2 reduction volatile products, including CO, CH4, C2H4, and C2H5OH, were simultaneously monitored in real-time using the operando MS technique Figure 1b, alongside Raman measurement. The yields of these products generally exhibited an increasing trend with rising current densities Figure 3a. Figure 3b presents the average ion currents of these products at different current densities, while Figure 3c displays the integral areas of the unidentified band at 1945 cm1. Notably, as the current density increased, there was a strong correlation between the generation rate of C2 products C2H4 and C2H5OH and the peak intensity at 1945 cm1. Both showed a synchronized changing profile, which was different from the generation rates of CO and CH4. This suggests that the band at 1945 cm1 likely corresponds to a key intermediate involved in the C2 products formation. Specifically, the band shift from 1834 cm1 to 1793 cm1 aligns well with the estimated value for COB Supporting Note 2. The high local pH at this interface Figure S9, generally believed to facilitate C-C coupling,59,60 leads to the rapid consumption and conversion of active COL. This explains why COL is not observed in operando Raman spectra. Moreover, in the preceding steps for CCO generation, protonation primarily occurs at the highly electronegative oxygen Oδ site rather than at carbon Cδ, for example, as seen in the step of COOH formation. Due to the restricted mobility of polyelectrolyte-tethered organic cations, a rigid hydrogen bonding network is maintained at the electrodepolyelectrolyte interface under negative potentials, with a high proportion of strongly hydrogen-bonded water sh-H2O. It is reasonable to infer that the Hδ in sh-H2O can readily interact with the Oδ in these oxygen-containing intermediates, facilitating direct protonation with interfacial water via the Eley-Rideal mechanism.61 However, for the further conversion of CCO, the protonation of α-C to form CHCO is thermodynamically more favorable.62 To elucidate the protonation process of CCO, we conducted density functional theory DFT calculations. The calculations demonstrate that the protonation of α-C atom via the Eley- Rideal mechanismwhere CCO reacts with dangling water molecules above the electrode surfaceis not feasible, restricted by the substantial spatial separation between them. Instead, due to the proximity of the α-C atom to the electrode surface, the only viable pathway for this protonation process follows the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism, where the reaction occurs with surface-adsorbed water H2O, Figure S14. Nonetheless, this pathway still needs to overcome a relatively high transition-state energy barrier of 0.89 eV Figure 4e. In addition, due to the low water content and the constraint imposed by the rigid hydrogen bonding network at the electrodepolyelectrolyte interface, the transport and adsorption of water molecules onto the electrode surface are significantly limited. Overall, the distinct electrodepolyelectrolyte interfacial structure shifts the rate-determining step from the usual C- C coupling to the CCO hydrogenation in the conversion of CO2 to C2 products. Conclusions In summary, we have investigated the CO2 reduction mechanism at the electrodepolyelectrolyte interface within a practical MEA electrolyzer by combining operando Raman and MS analyses. We successfully captured direct spectroscopic evidence of a key CCO intermediate for C2 products formation, which was further verified through 13C- and D- isotopic substitution experiments as well as AIMD calculations. Notably, the CCO intermediate has been rarely detected in previous studies on CO2 reduction in conventional liquid electrolytes. This observation is due to the distinct structural characteristics of the electrodepolyelectrolyte interface, including a relatively high local pH, lower water content, and a more rigid hydrogen bonding network in the interfacial water. These features favor the Eley-Rideal type hydrogenation and disfavor the Langmuir-Hinshelwood type hydrogenation in CO2 reduction, thus promoting the conversion of surface-active COL to CCO while limiting its further protonation. These findings can not only facilitate the design of efficient electrocatalytic interfaces in practical MEA electrolyzers for CO2 and pure water co-electrolysis, but also highlight the importance of developing operando spectroscopic methods for studying interfacial catalysis under MEA working conditions. Further efforts can be made to introduce a stable and reliable reference electrode into the MEA device, in order to probe changes in interfacial species at different electrode potentials, rather than just observing their variations relative to current densities. text: Phosphorus-Mediated Oxygen Vacancy Engineering in Cu2O for Highly Selective CO2 Electroreduction to Multicarbon Products Xiaoqing Mao,Zhongyuan Guo,Saiwu Yang, Yongjun Shen, Li Wei, Congcong Li, Hongliang Jiang, Hao Li, Huihui Li, and Chunzhong Li Cite This: https:doi.org10.1021acsnano.5c04602 Read Online ACCESS Metrics More Article Recommendations sı Supporting Information ABSTRACT: Copper Cu-based electrocatalysts are acknowledged as pivotal catalysts for the electroreduction of CO2 into multicarbon C2 products; however, achieving high C2 selectivity at industrial-level current densities remains a significant challenge. Herein, we propose a phosphorus P-doping mediation strategy to introduce an oxygen vacancy into the Cu2O lattice, resulting in a C2 Faradaic efficiency of 87.0 at a partial current density of 347.8 mAcm2. Mechanistic studies unveil that P dopants dynamically regulate the formation of high-density oxygen vacancies in Cu2O lattices through the formation and subsequent detachment of the PO bond, predominantly in the form of phosphite within an aqueous electrolyte environment. In situ Raman spectroscopy coupled with density functional theory calculations further reveals that the OV-rich structure optimizes the surface coverage of active CO intermediates. This microenvironment not only accelerates the energetically favorable CC coupling pathway but also suppresses competitive protonation reactions, thereby breaking the intrinsic activity-selectivity trade-off. Our work provides atomic-level insights into defect dynamics manipulation for designing high-rate CO2 conversion systems. KEYWORDS: oxygen vacancy, P-doping mediation, CO2 reduction reaction, CO intermediate, multicarbon products INTRODUCTION The excessive use of fossil fuels at the expense of increasing global carbon emissions has caused irreversible climatic changes. The electrochemical CO2 reduction reaction CO2RR, which converts CO2 into high-value-added and easily storable chemical energy, is an environmentally friendly approach with the potential to alleviate the energy crisis.1 Cu- based electrocatalysts have garnered significant attention due to the optimal CO binding energy on the Cu surface, facilitating CC coupling to C2 products. Up until now, a substantial number of researches have made considerable developments of Cu-based electrocatalysts through various strategies, including doping,24 ligand modification,57 do- main-limited space construction,8,9 and defects engineer- ing.1012 However, the sluggish kinetics and high CC coupling energy barrier of the CO2RR process, which involves multiple proton-coupled electron transfer, require high over- potential, leading to low selectivity C2 products. The creation of oxygen vacancies OVs is an effective strategy for the above issues, boosting the CO2RR performance by concurrently modifying the electronic structure and surface reactivity.13 The OVs, serving as fingerprint of the electronic structure of the catalysts, can effectively promote the transfer of electrons to the adsorbed CO2, thus lowering the energy barrier for CO2 electroreduction by enhancing CO2 activation and the adsorption of key intermediates.14,15 Second, it has been demonstrated that the presence of OVs enhances the charge transfer efficiency at the catalytic reaction interface by decreasing the charge transfer resistance, thus increasing the electrocatalytic reaction rate.15,16 Furthermore, it has been demonstrated that OVs can effectively suppress competitive HER activity by modulating the adsorption energy and electronic configuration of CO2RR intermediaries.17 Thus, it is of significant importance to develop Cu-based catalysts enriched with OVs. Nevertheless, the concentration and distribution of OVs exhibit

text: increasing the electrocatalytic reaction rate.15,16 Furthermore, it has been demonstrated that OVs can effectively suppress competitive HER activity by modulating the adsorption energy and electronic configuration of CO2RR intermediaries.17 Thus, it is of significant importance to develop Cu-based catalysts enriched with OVs. Nevertheless, the concentration and distribution of OVs exhibit high sensitivity to the synthesis conditions such as temperature,18 pressure,19 and gas composition.20 This sensitivity makes it challenging to achieve precise and reproducible control of OVs.21 In addition, despite Received: March 17, 2025 Revised: May 24, 2025 Accepted: May 27, 2025 Article www.acsnano.org XXXX American Chemical Society A https:doi.org10.1021acsnano.5c04602 ACS Nano XXXX, XXX, XXXXXX Downloaded via TSINGHUA UNIV on June 15, 2025 at 12:43:38 UTC. See https:pubs.acs.orgsharingguidelines for options on how to legitimately share published articles. the overall CO2RR being a reductive process, the presence of CO2 and potential intermediate products can generate a relatively oxidizing microenvironment. Oxygen in CO2 or other oxygen-containing species may fill the OVs, reducing their concentration and affecting the catalytic activity.22 When the partial pressure of CO2 is high, the probability of oxygen filling the vacancies increases. Therefore, these factors pose critical challenges for precise synthesis of Cu-based catalyst enriched OVs, as well as maintaining long-term stability in a desired state for optimal catalytic performance. Herein, we proposed a P-doping mediation strategy to precisely control the formation of OVs, combining the one- step liquid-phase method to obtain a surface P-doped Cu2O as-prepared PCu2O at room temperature and the in situ electrochemical pre-reduction process to achieve the successful construction of OVs OVsCu2O. The P-dopant is the key factor for the rapid formation of substantial OVs in the Cu2O lattice, primarily through the formation and subsequent detachment of PO bonds. The ultraviolet photoelectron spectroscopy UPS demonstrates that the OVs function as charge carriers, thereby facilitating electron transfer during the CO2RR. In situ Raman analysis indicates that the presence of OVs enhances the adsorption of CO intermediates, thus promoting the selectivity for C2 products. As a result, the OVsCu2O electrocatalysts achieved a C2 Faradaic efficiency FE of 87.0 at partial current density of 347.8 mAcm2, along with stable performance exceeding 30 h in a membrane electrode assembly MEA electrolyzer. RESULTS AND DISCUSSION Synthesis and Characterization. The OVsCu2O catalysts were synthesized through a two-step process involving P-doping follow by an in situ electrochemical reduction process Figures 1a and S1. Due to the significant electronegativity difference between P 2.19 and O 3.44, the electron cloud of P with electron-donating ability tends to shift toward O.23 This leads to a strong binding tendency between P and O, thereby facilitating the formation of PO bonds. The second- step of the in situ electrochemical reduction process plays a crucial role in accelerating the detachment of PO bonds, leading to the departure of O atoms from the Cu2O lattice and thus forming OVs to obtain OVsCu2O.24,25 The PO bonds desorb as P-containing species from the catalyst surface into the electrolyte such as phosphate, phosphite, or hypophos- phite in an aqueous electrolyte. According to the experimental characterizations, Cu2O200 was selected to study the effects of P dopant on the OVs formation. The pristine Cu2O200 and its corresponding P-doped models are shown Figure 2g. The OVs formation energy ΔEOVs,formation was employed to describe the tendency of OVs formation caused by P dopants, which was defined by ΔEOVs,formation EOVs EO EnPCu d2O200, where EOVs and EnPCu d2O200 represented the electronic energy of the P-doped models with and without OVs, respectively. EO was calculated from EH d2O and EH d2 EH d2O EH d2. The more negative the ΔEOVs,formation, the more likely to form OVs over Cu2O. Figure 2d demonstrates that the ΔEOVs,formation exhibits a tendency to decrease with an increase in the PCu ratio of the surface phase, suggesting that P dopants can contribute to the generation of OVs. When the ratio of PCu approaches to 0.6, the ΔEOVs,formation is demonstrably lower than that of pristine Cu2O, indicating that higher P dopant level is more likely to form OVs compared to pristine Cu2O. The electrochemically active surface area ECSA usually affects CO2RR activity, which was measured by double-layer capacitance Cdl on the basis of cyclic voltammograms for the OVsCu2O and pre-reduced reference Cu2O Figure S16. Based on the experimental results, it is known that almost all of the Cu2O material was reduced into metallic Cu during the pre-reduced process, so the fully reduced Cu2O200 with massive OVs, obtained by removing all of the O atoms from Cu2O200, was used for the subsequent CO2RR analysis. As a comparison, the CO2RR over the pristine Cu2O200 was also analyzed to study the effect of OVs on the crucial CC coupling step. The optimized configurations for the adsorption of different intermediates are displayed Figure S21. As depicted in Figure 4e, we found that the generation energy barrier of OCCO is 1.11 eV on fully reduced Cu2O200, which is noticeably lower than 1.73 eV observed on Cu2O200. The energy reduction from Cu2O200 to fully reduced Cu2O- 200 reveals that the presence of OVs facilitates CC coupling, further promoting CO2 conversion to C2 products. Additionally, the effects of OVs induced by P dopants on the reduction of C2 intermediates were further analyzed Figures S22 and S23, which revealed that the OVs can contribute to the generation of gaseous C2H4 and liquid products CH3CH2OH by decreasing the energy difference between CHCHO and CHCOH intermediates. In combination with the CO coupling Figure 4e, it is found that the limiting step for the generation of C2 products on Cu2O200 is from the CC coupling process, while OVs improve the CC coupling step, and the limiting step on fully reduced Cu2O200 is from the hydrogenation of the C2 intermediate OCCOH H eHOCCOH. Therefore, OVs modulate the electrochemical process to change the distribu- tion of C2 products, as reflected in Figure 3. CONCLUSIONS In summary, our work presents a catalyst enriched with OVs to achieve a high selectivity of 87.0 at a partial current density of 347.8 mAcm2 and stability over 30 h for the CO2RR toward C2 products. The experimental results, in situ characterization and DFT calculations provide solid evidence that the introduction of OVs enable selective adsorptionactivation of CO2 and reduction of energy barriers for CO2RR, thus promoting CC coupling and enhancing the selectivity of C2 products. These findings hold promise for providing clear insights into the production of OVs on Cu-based catalysts and developing a highly selective catalyst design strategy to boost the CO2RR activity. All electrochemical perform- ance measurements and LSV were conducted in a flowing cell GOSREL, Cp10 with an active area of 1 1 cm2. The flow cell comprises a gas flow chamber, a cathode chamber, and an anode chamber, which are separated by an anion exchange membrane Fumasep-FAB-PK-130. The gas diffusion electrode GDE acts as the cathode, serving as a separator between the gas chamber and the cathode chamber. The GDE was prepared as follows: Initially, 8 mg of electrocatalyst was dispersed in 5 mL of isopropanol and 10 μL of ACS Nano www.acsnano.org Article https:doi.org10.1021acsnano.5c04602 ACS Nano XXXX, XXX, XXXXXX G Nafion solution. Then, the mixture was dispersed by sonication for 30 min to form a homogeneous ink. At last, the ink was sprayed to a 3 3 cm2 gas diffusion layer with a theoretical electrocatalyst loading of 0.88 mg cm2. The prepared working electrode 1 1 cm2 and nickel foam 1 1 cm2 were used as the cathode and anode, respectively. The constant current mode was employed for the measurements of the CO2RR. The current density conditions tested were 250, 300, 350, 400, 450, and 500 mAcm2, with a reaction time of 10 min. The electrolyte was 1.0 M KHCO3 and was continuously circulated in the cathode and anode chambers with a flow rate of 5 mLmin1 by using a peristaltic pump. Abstract: Electrochemical nitrate reduction reaction NO3RR is a promising approach to simultaneously realize pollutant removal and ammonia generation. However, this process involves the transfer of eight electrons and nine protons along with multiple by-products, resulting in a significant challenge for achieving high ammonia yield and selectivity. Herein, we introduced bimetallic covalent organic frameworks catalysts with Cu and Co active sites to achieve a two- step tandem reaction, avoiding excessive nitrite accumulation and enabling efficient NO3RR. For the initial two-electron process, the Cu sites in the bimetallic catalyst exhibit a strong binding affinity with nitrate, promoting their conversion to nitrite. The Co sites enhance the supply and adsorption of active hydrogen and stabilize the subsequent six-electron process, thereby improving the overall catalytic efficiency. Introduction Ammonia NH3 remains not only an essential precursor in chemical industries,1 but also a next-generation hydrogen storage medium and carbon-neutral energy carrier.2 However, the conventional Haber-Bosch process for industrial NH3 synthesis involves high-energy consumption and generates significant greenhouse gas emissions.3 As an attractive alternative, electrocatalytic nitrate reduction reaction NO3RR for NH3 synthesis has emerged due to its environmental friendliness and mild reaction conditions.4 Alternative to nitrogen and nitric oxide,4c, 5 NO3 benefits from its lower dissociation energy, higher solubility, and rapid reduction kinetics at the liquid-solid interface, thus being regarded as a more promising N source for NH3 production.4a, 6 Additionally, NO3 is a prevalent harmful pollutant in contaminated groundwater, industrial wastewater, and nuclear emissions, which poses risks to both the environment and human health. Consequently, converting nitrate into the value-added product NH3 is environmentally beneficial and economically advantageous. The NO3RR process NO3 8e 9H NH3 3H2O, E0 0.69 V vs. RHE involves a complicated eight-electron and nice-proton transfer process,7 and is prone to generate by- product NO2, NO, NH2OH, N2H4, etc..8 This complex process can be divided into two consecutive reactions: a 2e process from NO3 to NO2 and a 6e process from NO2 to NH3.9 Matching the reactivity of two-step reactions is crucial to achieve high ammonia yield and Faradaic efficiency FE. Early studies have shown that Cu could effectively facilitate the adsorption of NO3 due to the similarity of energy levels between the d orbitals of Cu and the LUMO of nitrate.10 Additionally, the low hydrogen accumulation on the Cu11 surface promotes NO3 reduction while suppressing hydrogen evolution reaction HER.12 However, insufficient H supply may kinetically limit the hydrogenation step in the NO3RR.13 This calls for the rational regulation of water adsorption and enhanced supply of H 14 over the surface of Cu-based catalyst.15 The inherent oxyphilic nature and electronegativity of Co could facilitate H adsorption and supply,16 creating an excellent interfacial environment for the NO3 hydrogenation process while mitigating the formation of by- products. Hydrazone- linked COFs represent a promising platform for forming new metal coordination sites containing both N and O atoms after synthesis process, thereby ensuring robust stabilization of metal centers.23 Therefore, it can be envisioned that the chemical designability and tunability of hydrazone-linked COFs can not only provide a promising platform for manipulating the NO3RR process at the electrocatalytic interface, but also contribute to elucidating the cascade electrocatalytic mechanism and reaction pathway, as well as understanding the NO3RR catalytic process to improve ammonia yield and Faradaic efficiency. However, the research in this regard is scarcely reported. Herein, we introduced covalent organic frameworks electrocatalyst with bimetallic active sites to match the two-step cascade reaction, thus avoiding excessive nitrite accumulation and enabling an efficient NO3RR process through Cu-Co tandem mechanism. Focusing on the initial two-electron process, the Cu sites in the bimetallic catalyst exhibit a strong binding affinity with nitrate and promote their efficient conversion to nitrite. The Co sites enhance the supply and adsorption of active hydrogen during the later six-electron process, thereby improving the overall catalytic efficiency. Consequently, the CuCo bimetallic catalyst demonstrates superior ammonia yield and FE NH3 yield rate 20.8 mgh1cm2, FE 92.16 in 0.3 M nitrate, much higher than those of monometallic Cu and Co catalysts. Such a highly matched two-step process provides a feasible strategy for efficiently coupling the cascade process, thereby advances the efficiency and applicability of NO3RR. Then TTA-TPH was then dispersed in ethanol containing different concentrations of Cu ions, Co ions, or a mixture of Cu and Co ions. For TTA- TPH-CuCo, the Cu site significantly adsorbs NO3, serving as the adsorption and activation center in the NO3RR process. Subsequently, the -N-Co-O- interface simultaneously promotes the dissociation of H₂O and the supply of H to ensure the steady progress of the subsequent hydrogenation process. The tandem catalysis of Cu and Co optimizes the intermediate steps and transition states of the reaction, thereby accelerating the kinetics of the proton-coupled electron transfer reaction. Conclusion In summary, we have designed and fabricated a bimetallic TTA- TPH-CuCo catalysts with tandem active sites for the cascade conversion of nitrate to ammonia. Compared with the monometallic counterparts, TTA-TPH-CuCo achieves a high NH3 yield rate of 20.8 mgh1cm2 with FE of 92.16 in 0.3 M nitrate, outperforming most of the reported NO3RR electrocatalysts in the literature. Through in situ DEMS, in situ ATR-IRAS, and theoretical calculations, we have elucidated the cascade mechanism occurring over the TTA-TPH-CuCo. The Cu sites function as the activation centers for adsorption and the initial 2e process. The N-Co-O- interface promotes water adsorption and dissociation, facilitates the formation of H-rich interface and boosts the subsequent 6e process, thus accelerating efficient synthesis of ammonia. This work not only emphasizes the achievement of efficient NO3RR through matching a two-step tandem reaction, but also paves the way for designing highly efficient electrocatalysts for NO3RR and possible other reactions in which high selectivity is desired.
